'''J.R.R. Tolkien's signature and monogram''' are synonymous with Tolkien's works, and have a history of their own. Both are registered trademarks owned by the [[Tolkien Estate]].

==Signature history==
Tolkien's signature evolved over time. As early as [[1910]], he is recorded as having signed his name as "Ronald Tolkien" on an art piece titled ''[[Ruins at West End of White Abbey]]''.<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work", Image 10 </ref> In [[1913]] he signed his name as the more familiar "J.R.R. Tolkien" on his painting entitled [[Foxglove Year|''Foxglove Year'']]<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work", Image 17</ref>, which accompanied a poem he wrote by the same name. A further evolution of Tolkien's signature is visible from a [[1923]] signing of a book he owned called ''The Latin Poems.''<ref>{{Cite web|articleurl=https://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/wiwimod/index.php?page=Bloomsbury+689|articlename=Bloomsbury Sale #689|author=Tolkien Collector's Guide|dated=16 July 2009|accessed=9 November 2024}}</ref>
<gallery heights="60">
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Signature 1910.png|J.R.R. Tolkien signing as "Ronald Tolkien" in 1910.
File:J.R.R Tolkien Signature 1913.png|Tolkien's signature from his 1913 painting ''Foxglove Year.''
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Signature Later.png|A typical example of Tolkien's more well known later signature.
File:The Latin Poems (Tolkien signature).jpg|A 1923 signature from a book of Latin Poems.
</gallery>
==Forgeries==

==Monogram history==

===Early monograms===
Tolkien's first recorded use of a monogram was on a sketch titled ''[[Lyme Regis Harbor from the Drawing Room Window of the Cups Hotel]]'' in [[1906]]<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work", Image 8</ref> and included just a "J", an "R", and a "T". Another monogram appeared on a [[1911]] illustration titled [[Lamb's Farm, Gedling]]. The first use of the two-"R" motif (with one "R" being flipped) was in [[1912]] on a sheet containing two sketches, ''[[Keystone of Door]]'' and ''[[Gargoyles, South Side, Lambourn]]''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work", Image 13</ref>. [[1913]] saw the first use of the four dot design in a monogram on a piece titled ''[[Grownupishness]]''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Visions, Myths, and Legends", Image 35</ref>. Another 1913 monogram contained the first instance of two uses of the four dots design on a piece titled ''[[Pagent House Gardens, Warwick]]''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work", Image 14</ref>. In [[1914]], a symmetrical monogram design appeared in the first text about [[Middle-earth]]'s genesis called ''[[Tanaqui]]'',<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Visions, Myths, and Legends", Image 43</ref> which depicted an early version of the mountain [[Taniquetil]]. In [[1918]], a monogram closely resembling the final monogram appeared on a piece entitled ''[[Gipsy Green]].''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "Early Work"</ref><gallery heights="120">
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1906.png|Tolkien's first recorded monogram from 1906.
File:JRR Tolkien Monogram 1911.png|A 1911 Tolkien Monogram that appeared on the illustration ''Lamb's Farm, Gedling.''
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1912.png|Tolkien's first recorded use of a two-R version of the monogram from 1912.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1913.png|Tolkien's first use of the "four dots" in 1913.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1913 2.png|Tolkien's first monogram utilizing two instances of the "four dot" motif.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1914.png|A symmetrical Tolkien monogram from 1914.
File:J.R.R Tolkien Monogram 1918.png|A 1918 monogram from Tolkien's painting ''Gipsy Green.''
</gallery>

===Monogram usage in ''The Hobbit''===
The publication of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' in [[1937]] saw the use of several unique monograms. An asymmetrical variation showed up in the ink illustration titled ''Trolls. Another'' new symmetrical monogram showed up in one of Tolkien's illustrations titled ''[[The Hill: Hobbiton-across-the Water]]''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "The Hobbit", Image 98</ref>. A similar 1937 monogram appears on the dust jacket of the book. Another 1937 monogram appears on the illustration titled ''[[Conversation with Smaug]]'', and is highly reminiscent of Tolkien's "modern" monogram<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]'', "The Hobbit", Image 133</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|articleurl=https://www.drawinside.com/en-us/blogs/artist-studio/evolution-of-the-tolkien-monogram|articlename=Evolution and story of the Tolkien monogram from 1906 to 1981|author=Pierre Emmanuel Godet|dated=6 August 2021|accessed=31 October 2024}}</ref>.<gallery>
File:JRR Tolkien Mongoram 1937 2.png|An asymmetrical monogram from 1937's ''Trolls'' illustration.
File:JRR Tolkien Monogram 1937.png|Monogram from 1937's ''The Hill:'' ''Hobbiton Across the Water''
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1937 2.png|A 1937 Tolkien monogram that appeared on the dust jacket of ''The Hobbit''.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1937 3.png|A 1937 Tolkien monogram that is reminiscent of the "modern" monogram.
</gallery>

===Final version of Tolkien's monogram===
[[File:JRRT.jpeg|thumb|Final monogram.|left|184x184px]]The final version of Tolkien's monogram appeared in [[1976]] on the title page of ''[[Drawings by Tolkien]]'', the catalogue of a J.R.R. Tolkien exhibition of the same name. The exhibition was held by Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, in between 1976 and [[1977]]. Curiously, the monogram was horizontally inverted, which was likely a mistake of the printer who produced the catalogues.

A correctly oriented version of the monogram later appeared on the spine of ''[[Unfinished Tales]]'' in [[1980]]. However, this version omitted the two "four-dots" designs.

The two groups of four dots were added but were used inconsistently until [[1981]], when the final version of the monogram was designed and used on the cover of ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''.<ref name=":0" /><gallery>
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1976.png|The inverted 1976 Tolkien monogram from ''[[Drawings by Tolkien]]''.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1980.png|A 1980 Tolkien monogram on the spine of ''[[Unfinished Tales]]''.
File:J.R.R. Tolkien Monogram 1981.png|The final Tolkien monogram as it appeared on the cover of 1981's ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''.
</gallery>

==Coincidence==
*It is entirely a coincidence that the monogram closely resembles the Chinese character "[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9D%9F#Definitions 束]", which means "bundle" or "to bind".
